column4: I need help resizing LVM partitions.  Can't even get started, sadly.
It's nice and easy.  You go "sudo lvextend" :)
No program lvextend" found for your current version of LVM"
If you want to extend the underlying LVM system, that's slightly different.  What exactly are you trying to do.
I have sda2 as a pile of disk space, subdivided to become my /home, /, /multimedia, etc.  I need to steal space from one and give it to another within that.
So, where is the LVM in that?

Well, let's see if I can remember this right...  I have one actual disk, split into two partitions by normal means - I believe that would be two "physical volumes" then.  Only one of those has any lvm stuff then.  Under that, there is one volume group, and numerous logical volumes.  I need to shrink one logical volume and increase another to fill the space.
Ah, that makes more sense.  So, since you need to shrink at least one of your LVs, you'll need to have that volume unmounted.
I'm on a Live CD atm, so everything is.
Awesome.  However, the livecd doesn't start LVM :)
So, I *belive* you'll need to install the lvm2 package, then run "sudo /etc/init.d/lvm-common start", or something like that.

Then you want to shrink the filesystem on the LV.  That'll need to be either "resize2fs" or "resize_reiserfs", depending on the filesystem (ext2/3 or reiser).  If it's not one of those two, then I'm not sure how you can resize the fs :)
Ah, the init start was the step I was missing I think.
resize2fs works for ext3, ya?
Yes.  At least, that's what the man page says :)
Do you know how to calculate sizes in blocks?
Uurgh.  No.  Doesn't resize2fs support using something sane, like GB?
Maybe it does - the tutorial I'm reading could well be outdated.  Time for some man page reading.
How can I list their current sizes without mounting to get an idea of what to resize to?
I don't know.  I think you'll have to mount.
'k
